texts.es:
Jose, tiene 59 años de edad, reside en el municipio de Patuca, su familia esta conformada por su esposa quien se dedica a los quehacerse del hogar y sus dos hijos quienes estudian en la escuela. 

Jose inició a trabajar desde muy pequeño, recuerda que no le gustaba mucho ir a la escuela y se escapaba para ir a la finca de cafe de su vecino para ayudar con las labores. Despues el tiempo fue pasando y Jose fue involucrandose mas en el negocio del cafe y cuando llegó a la adultez decidió iniciar su propio cultivo de cafe y actualmente tiene sembradas 22 manzanas de tierra.  

Con el apoyo de este prestamo Jose podrá comprar canastas para la recoleccion del cafe, pagar la mano de obra por la recoleccion y el pago del transporte para sacar su cosecha al mercado. Con el apoyo de este prestamo espera aumentar sus ganancias y de esta forma mejorar la economía de su hogar. Este es su primer prestamo en FAMA y espera cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas puntualmente.
texts.en:
Jose, age 59, resides in the municipality of Patuca. His family is comprised of his wife, who dedicates herself to housework, and their two children, who go to school.

Jose began working when he was very small. He recalls that he did not much like going to school, and he used to leave in order to go to a neighbor’s coffee farm to help with the work. As time passed, Jose involved himself more in the coffee business, and when he became an adult he decided to begin his own coffee farm. Currently, he has 38 acres of planted land.

With the support of this loan, Jose will be able to buy baskets for collecting coffee, pay laborers for the harvest, and pay for transport in order to bring his harvest to market. With the support of this loan he hopes to increase his earnings and in this way improve the economy of his household. This is his first loan with FAMA and he hopes to make all his payments on time.

loans.use: to purchase baskets for collecting coffee, pay laborers for the harvest, and pay for transport in order to bring his harvest to market.

loans.name: Julie

texts.en:
Julie is 34 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with one child. 

Julie has a food shop or sari-sari store that sells canned goods, snacks and beverages. She has had this business for two years. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

Julie has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Julie hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is fifty years old, married to James, and blessed with one child. She runs a cereal shop and plans to use the loan to add more stock to resell in her business like beans, rice and maize. She has been earning a monthly income of about 200,000 KES.

She has been in business for three years and plans to plow the anticipated profit back into the business to meet existing demands. This will be her second loan with KADET LTD. Her hope is to open up a general store.

loans.use: To add stock to her business, like beans, rice and maize.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Even though Cecilia grew up in difficult circumstances, she is now a successful petty trader. She is married to a fisherman and has five children. 

She operates a provision shop at Elmina located in the Central Region. She sells provisions like Cowbell milk, toothbrushes, margarine, tissue rolls, and sugar. Cecilia has been in this business for several years. She uses all of her income to support her husband and to feed and provide for the entire family. 

Cecilia’s loan will be used to purchase an increased amount of Cowbell milk, coffee, toothbrushes, margarine, tissue rolls, and sugar for sale. She hopes to use the new profits to grow her current business and to increase her capital base. 

In the future, Cecilia wants to expand her business into neighboring villages and give her children a better education.

loans.use: to purchase Cowbell milk, coffee, toothbrushes, margarine, tissue rolls, and sugar for sale.

loans.name: Vanny

texts.en: K. Vanny is a very busy woman. In addition to her fruit sales business, she spends much time taking care of her four daughters, two sons, and grandmother. K. Vanny earns about $3.75 from her fruit sales each day. Her husband is a motor bike taxi driver, and earns about $2.50 a day. Her oldest son also works, and earns about $2.25 per day. She is applying for a $1,000 loan. She is planning to use $300 to help her husband purchase a new motor bike so that he can increase his taxi business. She plans to use the other $700 to help pay for the new home they would like to build. She is very excited about being able to provide her family with a better home, and she anticipates increased income from the new motor bike.

loans.use: Sell old motor bike and buy new, and build house.

loans.name: Fotu

texts.en: Fotu is married with one daughter. After school she was unable to find a good-paying job in her field of training, so she decided to start her own business of growing and selling bananas. She has been in business now for 2 years. With their support, her husband and her relatives have helped her business be successful. Her main goal is to provide the best bananas to meet her clients’ expectations, and to attract new customers to her market. Her existing clients that she has served for the past two years have helped promote the dynamic growth of her business. Successful, stable growth in Fotu’s business has also help provide employment for the relatives who have helped her, and a more secure future for her family.

loans.use: Buy organic fertilizers, pesticides, and farming implements

loans.name: Saleuleu

texts.en: Saleuleu lives at Falelauniu, which is a place of coconuts. This is where Saleuleu’s payment comes from. She sells these coconuts at the market everyday and earns about $300 a day. Saleuleu’s children collect the coconuts and she will rent a village car to deliver her coconuts to the market.

loans.use: Purchase coconuts

loans.name: Arminda Esperanza

texts.es:
Hello, my name is Arminda Esperanza, I’m a merchant. I have a small business of selling new clothes, located in a strategic place of my city. I have been doing this type of business for the past 3 years. It generates an income to cover my family’s expenses. At present my three children are in school, therefore I need to improve my income. In order to do it I need to buy more merchandise to have a larger variety and I don’t have the capital for such investment.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer.

Hola mi nombre es Arminda Esperanza, soy Comerciante, cuento con un pequeño negocio de venta de ropa nueva, ubicado en un lugar estratégico de mi ciudad, tengo 3 años de dedicarme a este tipo de actividad, la que me genera ingresos para cubrir los gastos de mi familia, actualmente mis tres hijos están estudiando, por lo que necesito mejorar los ingresos y para poder hacerlo tengo surtir mas el negocio y no cuento con el capital para tal inversión.

loans.use: Buy spandex skirts, underwear, T-shirts and shirts for men and boys, blouses for women, etc

loans.name: Marie

texts.en: Marie L. is forty-six years old and married with five children.  Her husband works for the government as a sanitary officer but his salary is insufficient to meet the family expenses.  L. started selling fish in Magburaka market in northern Sierra Leone to increase the family's income.  She is requesting  a loan of $200 to expand her fish business.

loans.use: Expand her fish business and increase her profits

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.es:
Elizabeth is a student at the public University of El Alto and works selling crackers wholesale at a city fair in El Alto. This is her main source of income and allows her to cover her living expenses and her studies. She lives in the Huayna Potosí area of the city of El Alto.

She will use this loan to buy more inventory to meet demand for her products. This is her first loan with Impro and she has been prequalified.

Translated from Spanish by Rosario McFaull, Kiva Volunteer.

Elizabeth es estudiante de la Universidad Publica El Alto (UPEA) y comerciante de galletas al por mayor, mismas que distribuye en la feria 16 de julio de la Ciudad de El Alto, es su principal fuente de ingreso con lo que cubre sus estudios y su alimentación; vive en la Zona Huayna Potosí de la Ciudad de El Alto. El crédito requiere para incrementar su mercadería y así satisfacer la demanda que tiene en su mercado. Es el primer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada permite aprobarle el préstamo solicitado.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more wood for her husband's carpentry business.

loans.name: Djavanshir

texts.en: Djavanshir was born in 1983. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli town, now settled in Fuzuli region, in the Kurdmakhmudlu village. A single man, Djavanshir has been as a taxi driver for two years. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy spare parts.

loans.use: to buy spare parts

loans.name: Arshad

texts.en: Arshad J. lives in Amirzeyidli village of Beylagan, a small city in Azerbaijan. He is 51 years old, married and has four children. He is engaged in cattle-breeding. He started his business 10 years ago. He needs a loan in the amount of $1075 and he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Grace

texts.fr:
Grâce T. (the woman seated with a comb in hand) is 25 years old, married, and the mother of one child. She has been the owner of a hair salon named Grace for three years. She professionally manages her salon and is thinking of bolstering her salon by acquiring two hair dryers. She is also thinking of creating a more welcoming environment by buying an electric fan.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Madame Grâce T. (femme assise avec peigne en main), âgée de 25 ans, mariée et mère de 01 enfant est propriétaire d’un salon de coiffure dénommée coiffure la Grâce) depuis 03 ans. Elle gère son salon avec professionnalisme et pense renforcer la capacité de son salon par l’acquisition de deux séchoirs et améliorer le cadre d’accueil par l’achat d’un ventilateur.

loans.use: To buy two hair dryers and an electric fan

loans.name: Zainabu's Ukombozi Group

texts.en:
Zainabu is 33 years old and is married with one child, age 13 years old. She and her husband also take care of two other people, aged 28 and 35. Zainabu has been selling clothes since 2001. She works every day from 8 am to 5 pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in clothes sales and food vending.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Bibirokiya

texts.ru:
Bibirokiya R. lives in the Khuroson area. She is 52 years old, married and has 3 children. She has a community college degree. Bibirokiya buys and re-sells sheep and goats. She buys the animals at the local market, as cheaply as she can. She then keeps and feeds them for about 1 month and then re-sells them at a higher price. She has been doing this for over 3 years. Bibirokiya's husband is a pensioner, but the pension is very small. The animal sales are the only income for her family. Bibirokiya would like to use the loan to buy some lambs. She plans to repay the loan within 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Olga Espira, Kiva volunteer.

Раматова Бибирокия жительница района Хуросон. Ей 52 года, замужем ,имеет 3 детей.Образование средние. Бибирокия занимается животноводством. Она разводит мелкий рогатый скот. Клиентка покупает на местном рынке мелкий рогатый скот( барашков и коз) по дешевле.Откармливает их 1 месяц и перепродает местным жителям по более выгодной цене. Занимается этой деятельностью более 3 лет. Муж клиентки пенсионер, получает очень маленькую пенсию. Животноводство является единственным источником дохода ее семьи. На кредит Бибирокия хочет купить молодых ягнят для откормки. Планирует погасить кредит в течние 10 месяцев.

loans.use: To buy lambs

loans.name: Sajida's Group

texts.en:
Sajida, wife of M. Sarwar has the business of trading wheat. She has one son and one daughter. Their son is in kindergarten. Sajida and her husband are willing to educate their children because they think that through education they will be able to face every situation very independently. She successfully completed a loan from Asasah, a microfinance institution. She needs a loan to invest in her wheat business, so that they get a lot of profit because this is the wheat season.

She has been joined in her group by a few more members. Haleema B. needs a loan to start a fruit cart business. Bashiran B. wants a loan to make iron boxes. Maqboola B. wants to expand her cigarette shop. Naseem B. needs a loan to start a workshop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: These women would like to expand their businesses and improve their financial conditions.

loans.name: Esther Kyeswa's Group

texts.en:
Esther is the leader of 4 members. She is 28 years old and married with 3 children. Her children are 2, 5, and 12 years old and all attend school. The community she lives and works in is urban and is a slum within a low-lying area that floods in the rainy season.

Esther sews sponges at home and has been in business for 4 years. She sells her sponges to others who have booths at shops and markets in Kampala. The market for her business is large, and her main challenges are the high costs of materials and the lack of enough water during the dry season.

Esther plans on using this loan to buy additional raw materials for her business, pay her children’s school fees, and provide food for her family. She has successfully paid back 10 loans and in doing so has been able expand her business. In addition, she hopes to one day fulfill her dream of buying a plot of land where she could eventually build a house.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials for her business

loans.name: Isabel

texts.es:
Isabel is the mother of two children who are still in high school and she works selling kebabs on a corner of the plaza. This dish consists of pieces of grilled cow heart accompanied by potatoes. She would like to have an air-conditioned space to sell her food, but she doesn’t have enough money. When her earnings aren’t sufficient, she tries to find customers for whom she can wash clothing and earn a little bit of extra money. Isabel requests this loan in order to rent a space where she can sell her kebabs in a more comfortable and receptive manner.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva volunteer.

Isabel es madre de 2 pequeños, que aún están en el colegio. Ella se dedica a la venta de anticuchos que vende en una esquina de la plaza. Este plato que consiste en pedazos de corazón de res a la parrilla acompañados de papa. A ella le gustaría tener un local, que esté acondicionado para la venta de comida, pero no tiene el dinero para esto. Cuando el dinero no es suficiente, busca la forma de encontrar clientes para lavar ropa y ganar un dinero extra. Isabel presenta su pedido de préstamo para alquilar un local donde pueda vender sus anticuchos de una manera más cómoda y acogedora para sus clientes.

loans.use: Rent a space where she can sell her kebabs

loans.name: Džemila

texts.en:
Džemila is a 40 year old woman from the village of Šerići, near the town ŽIvinice. She is divorced, and she works in a coffee bar. Her monthly salary is 600 KM. Because her salary is not sufficient to support her family, Džemila also sells cosmetic products from home to make additional money. Džemila lives with her parents, and she has an eighteen year old daughter.

This is Džemila’s second loan from our foundation, and she is asking for 600 KM. Džemila intends to use the money to buy more cosmetic products to sell from home to help support her family.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetic products to sell from home.

loans.name: Leopoldina Da Carmeni

texts.pt:
Leopoldina tem34 ano, nasceu em Inhambane e cresceu na Matola. Ela é viuva e mãe de 4filhos com idades compriendida entre 15anos á 6meses, só o primeiro vai a escala porque o segundo é mudo e em Namaacha nào tem escola para crianças especiais.Leopoldina  e a sua familia  se mudaram para Namaacha uma vila na fronteira com Swazilândia  em 1996  quando o marido trabalhava na Fronteira com guarda-fronteira.

Leopoldina estudou apenas até 8ªclase e a única forma de ganhar avida para ela era entrar no mundo dos negócios. Em 1998 abriu um salão de cabeleleiro na sua propria residência uma vez que já tinha trabalhado como cabeleleira na sua infancia, teve bons resultados, mas 2006 o marido fica doente e ela teve que gastar todo fundo no tratamento da doença do marido que não resistiu  e  merdeu a vida em 2007. Apois essa desgraça leopoldida  ficou sem dinheiro para continuar com o seu negócio, com  3fihos para criar e gravida de 6meses só contava com ajuda do seu Pai. Três mêses depois ela  recebeu uma indemnização no serviço do marido e preferiu deixar na conta a prazo para os filhos porque para alem da quele valor começou a receber uma pensão mensal de 2,000.00mt. Com ajuda da hluvuku leopoldina transformou o antigo salão numa barraca onde vende produtos de primeira nessecidade, tem bons resultados conseque criar seus filhos e consegue poupar os 2,000.00mtn.
 
Este é o segundo emprestimo dela com Hluvuku e o primeiro com Kiva. O primeiro de 15,000.00mtn foram usados na compra de produtos para sua barraca e este segundo de 25,000.00mtn seram usados para mesmo fim. Pretende futuramente pedir outros emprestimos para investir no negócio de criação e venda de  frangos. Na foto Leopodina esta com seu filho.
texts.en:
Leopoldina is 34 years old, was born in Inhambane, and grew up in Matola. She is a widow and mother of four children, between 6 months and 15 years old. Only the oldest attends school because the second-oldest is mute, and there are no schools for children with special needs in Namaacha. Leopoldina and her family moved to Namaacha, a village on the border of Swaziland, in 1996 when her husband worked there as a border guard.

Leopoldina studied through only 8th grade, and the sole way for her to earn a living was to enter the workforce. Having worked as a barber in her youth, in 1998 she opened a hair salon in her home and was successful. In 2006, however, her husband became sick, and she had to spend all their money to treat him. He did not withstand the illness and lost his life in 2007. After this tragedy, Leopoldina had no money to continue her business. With three children to raise and six months pregnant, she counted on just her father’s help. Three months later she received an indemnity/benefit payment for her husband’s service. For her children, she opted to leave the funds in the account for the length of the term because in addition to the original amount, she began to receive a monthly pension of 2,000 meticais (MTn). With the help of Hluvuku (Kiva’s Field Partner), Leopoldina transformed the old salon into a shop where she sells basic necessities. She has had positive results and is able to raise her children and to save 2,000 MTn.

This is her second loan with Hluvuku and her first with Kiva. She used the first loan of 15,000 MTn to buy products for her shop, and will use this second loan of 25,000 MTn to do the same. In the future she intends to ask for more loans to invest in a chicken-selling business. In the photo Leopoldina appears with her son.

Translated from Portuguese by April Newman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase stock in her shop

loans.name: Kpohoenou

texts.fr: Né en 1979 à Momé-Hagou, Monsieur H. Kpohoenou vit actuellement à Amégnran où il exerce son métier de photographe. Très entreprenant et actif, il a réussit à se procurer des appareils de qualité qui lui permettent de réaliser de bonnes prestation à ses clients. Cependant, les revenus tirés de son métier ne lui permettent pas d’assurer le nécessaire à sa famille. Ainsi, il veut diversifier ses sources de revenu en achetant une moto qu’il mettra en circulation pour le transport en commun.
texts.en:
Born in 1979 in Momé-Hagou, Mr. Kpohoenou H. currently lives in Amégnran, where he practices his trade as a photographer. A very entrepreneurial and active man, he succeeded in procuring quality cameras, which enable him to serve his clients well. Yet the income derived from his work doesn't permit him to ensure what is necessary for his family. And so, he wants to diversify his sources of income by buying a motorbike that he will put to use as a taxi.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a moto taxi

loans.name: Betty

texts.es: Betty es viuda, tiene 46 años y es madre de 4 hijos, siendo 3 de ellos independientes, viviendo en la actualidad con el último de sus hijos quien está estudiando. Ella se dedica a confeccionar ropa solo para niños y niñas en todos los modelos, esta labor la viene realizando desde hace 4 años atrás. Lo que le gusta de su trabajo es  que sus clientes tienen una confianza hacia su buena labor y la recomiendan  mucho a sus amistades. Le es muy rentable porque la gama de clientes que tiene están con ella desde el momento en que puso su taller, entonces su clientela no disminuye, al contrario aumenta poco a poco. Le va muy bien. Este es ya su segundo préstamo con MFP. Con el dinero solicitado quiere comprar una máquina remalladora, además de comprar más materiales como: agujas, telas, hilos, etc.
texts.en:
Betty is a 46-year-old widow and mother of four, three of which are grown and independent, so she now lives with her youngest who is still in school. For four years she has worked sewing children’s clothing in all styles. What she enjoys about her business is the confidence her clients have in her work and the resulting referrals she receives to their friends. This is very lucrative for her because she’s retained the majority of clients with which she started when she first opened her shop and her client base has not diminished; to the contrary, it grows bit by bit. She is doing well. This is her second loan with MFP. She wants to buy an overlock machine, as well as materials such as needles, fabric, thread, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Pamela Carreón, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase an overlock machine

loans.name: Joséphine

texts.en:
Joséphine A. is the mother of six children, all of whom are now married. She does not know the date of her birth. Joséphine buys cookies in Nigeria cheaply, and then sells them in Dantokpa Market in central Cotonou. Five years ago another woman showed her how to buy goods in Nigeria, and she began making the trip a few hours east to buy in bulk. She estimates that she receives about 20 clients per day. In the current economic climate, her goals are modest, but she hopes to sell more cookies in the future.

Alidé means “another path always exists for the most poor” in Fon, the principal tribal language of Cotonou, Benin. Benin is a small country in West Africa sandwiched between Togo and Nigeria. GDP per capita stands at $1,500 and poverty is endemic to the capital city of Cotonou. Alidé operates at seven different locations in and around Cotonou to ensure that those who need help can help themselves through small loans.

loans.use: Purchase of cookies

loans.name: Helen Lorena

texts.es:
Helen pertenece al Bancomunal Niño Divino
Helen es conviviente, tiene 25 años  tiene dos hijos de 8 y 3 años vive en casa de su suegra les ha dado el segundo piso para que vivan allí con su esposo, se vio en la necesidad de trabajar por que falta dinero para cubrir sus necesidades  
En Finca ella ha encontrado que le dan prestamos con menor interés y ella solicita un préstamo de 400 soles para la compra de ropa de niño y venderla ya tiene pedidos
Los sueños de Helen son le gustaría tener un puesto de ropa o tener un negocio propio, acabar de construir su casa, terminar el colegio y ser maestra de educación inicial
texts.en:
Helen belongs to the Nino Divino community bank. She is 25 years old and has two children, 8 and 3 years old, respectively. She lives in the house of her mother-in-law who has given her and her family the second floor of the house. She saw that she had to work when there wasn't enough money to cover her family's basic needs. She found that Finca provided loans at lower interest rates and is applying for a 400-soles loan to buy children's clothing that she will resell to customers who have already placed orders with her. Helen's hopes for the future are to have a shop or stand for setting up her own business, to build a house of her own, to finish school and to become a teacher.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise for resale.

loans.name: Dezi's Group

texts.en:
Dezi N. is the chairperson of "Bbogo Women’s Group" in Lugazi. She is a farmer growing bananas ‘matooke’ (a kind of banana), potatoes, and maize plantations on her family piece of land which food is both for sale and home consumption. In addition to farming, she prepares local brew known as "waragi" for sale, using a certain kind of yellow banana which she has also planted on the same family land.

Dezi is 42 years old and married with 10 children of whom 6 are girls and 4 are boys, while she cares for 5 grand-children. The loans have helped Dezi plus her other members in the group to recapitalize their businesses and this time round, Dezi would like a loan to buy more bananas for making "waragi" enough for her customers, as well as employing labour / manpower on her farm since now is the beginning of the rainy season. She is grateful for all her previous loans from Pearl Microfinance; for she is a better person now both in business and in family.

loans.use: buying more bananas for making her local brew and paying for manpower for her farm

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Charity is 32 years old and is married with 5 children. Charity lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells food and she hopes to expand her business and increase her profits. Charity hopes for the loan of N50,000 ($350 USD) to purchase more food to sell. She says "thanks" to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more food to sell

loans.name: Marleny  Nelly,

texts.es:
Marleny empezó con el negocio de venta de productos alimentarios surtidos con una tienda en Lima centro. Lamentablemente hace 12 años  su única hermana falleció, entonces Marleny se mudó a Matucana para cuidar a su familia.
Como ya tenía experiencia en este comercio, se juntó a uno de sus hermanos para empezar con una tienda de abarrotes en Matucana. Empezaron con pocos productos, y con el tiempo fueron creciendo. Sus ganancias las utiliza para cubrir los gastos de la crianza de sus tres hijos de 15, 12 y 5 años, y las que le sobran las junta a las de sus otros hermanos para cuidar a su mamá.
Marleny es conviviente, y con su pareja también tiene un negocio de tejidos desde hace 6 años. Tienen unas maquinas industriales, y los productos que ella teje él los vende en el centro comercial Gamarra, uno de los mayores centros comerciales de micro empresarios en Lima.
Ya lleva 3 años con los préstamos de EDAPROSPO, y a sus 36 años le gustaría en el futuro tener un negocio más grande. Está conversando con sus hermanos para abrir un restaurante o un hotel como negocio familiar.
texts.en:
Marleny began a business selling food products in central Lima. Sadly, twelve years ago her only sister passed away and Marleny moved to Matucana to care for her family. As she already has experience with commerce, she joined one of her brothers to begin a grocery store in Matucana. They began with a few products and grew with time. Their profits are used to cover the expense of the raising of her three children of 15, 12, and 5 years, and further profits are used to care for their mother. Marleny has a long-term partner who also is in the business of fabrics for six years. They have industrial sewing machines, and the products they make are sold in the shopping center Gamarra, one of the shopping centers in Lima. She has worked with EDAPROSPO, an affiliate of Kiva for 3 years, and at her 36 years she would like to have a larger business in the future. She is talking with her brothers about opening a hotel or restaurant as a family business.

Translated from Spanish by Lois Parshley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investing in fabrics for her business.

loans.name: Adekunle

texts.en: Adekunle is 33 years old and single. He sells planks. He has been in this business for a long time. He is requesting the loan amount of N 100,000 to purchase more planks to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more planks to sell

loans.name: Kokou

texts.fr: Kokou K. est un jeune homme de 28 ans, célibataire sans enfants. il tient un cabinet de traitement de texte, de photocopie et de vente des accessoires de matériels informatiques. Cette activité lui est rentable. Il souhaite avec ce crédit accroître la taille de son activité en payant de nouveaux appareils qui lui permettront de mieux exécuter ses tâches. Il compte sur cette opportunité pour améliorer les conditions de sa vie.
texts.en:
Kokou K. is a young man, 28 years of age, single and without children. He maintains an shop with equipment for text editing, photocopying and the sale of computer accessories and materials. This is a profitable business for him. With this loan he hopes to increase his business by buying new equipment, allowing him to improve his operation. He expects that this opportunity will improve his living conditions.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a new phorocopier and computer accessories for resale.

loans.name: Kely Betty

texts.es:
La señora Kely Betty R. C.  tiene 37 años, pertenece al Banco Comunal Virgen del Carmen y vive en el sector de Cochaya en el caserío de Salpo, provincia de Otuzco, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Estudió hasta sexto ciclo de educación superior pero no pudo concluir por falta de recursos económicos.
Se casó a los 25 años y aun no tiene hijos. Su actividad económica principal es la venta de insumos para la preparación de alimentos en una pequeña bodega.
Con su primer crédito de 300 soles que canceló en cuatro cuotas compró fertilizantes para agricultura.
Con este crédito de 800 soles que será cancelado en 6 cuotas comprará víveres para su bodega (arroz, azúcar, pan y bebidas gaseosas)
Kely desea comprarse una casa en Trujillo.
texts.en:
Mrs. Kely Betty R. C., 37, belongs to the Virgen del Carmen community bank. She lives in the Cochaya sector, Salpo village, Otuzco province, La Libertad department, Perú. She attended school up until the sixth cycle of secondary education. She could not finish for lack of economic resources. She got married when she was 25; she does not yet have children. Her primary business is selling supplies for food preparation in a small mini market. With her first loan of 300 PEN, which she repaid in four payments, she bought fertilizer for farming. With this loan for 800 PEN, which she will repay in six payments, she will buy supplies for her mini market (rice, sugar, bread, soft drinks). Kely wishes to buy a house in Trujillo.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies for her mini market (rice, sugar, bread, soft drinks)

loans.name: Mario

texts.es:
Mario Martínez es macatero hace mas de 15 años. Empezó solo vendiendo remeras pero hoy en día posee todo tipo de ropas, calzados manteles, zapatillas, y ya está empezando a traer electrodomésticos por pedidos de sus clientes, posee también dos vendedores para las distintas ciudades del Dpto. de cordillera. 

El señor Mario comenta que las ventas bajaron pero que el se ingenia para conseguir mas clientes y expandirse hacia lugares en donde no visitaba.

Los préstamos otorgados por la Fundación Paraguaya lo invirtieron en la compra de mercaderías para la venta.

El señor Mario manifiesta su agradecimiento por el apoyo constante que le brinda la Fundación Paraguaya para el fortalecimiento de su actividad, y a la vez espera contar siempre con la ayuda recibida de la institución.
texts.en:
Mario Martínez has been a traveling salesman in rural areas for more than 15 years. He began selling T-shirts but today offers all types of clothing, shoes, aprons, and gym shoes and is now selling electrical appliances at the request of his customers. He also has two sales representatives that serve the various cities of the mountainous area. Mr. Martínez says that sales are down, but he has managed to get more customers and has expanded to new areas. The loan from the Fundación Paraguaya will be invested in inventory. Mr. Martínez gives thanks for the persevering support of the Fundación Paraguaya, which has strengthened his activity. At the same time, he hopes he will always be able to count on the assistance of this institution.

Translated from Spanish by Jeff Schell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of clothing, shoes, T-shirts, etc.

loans.name: Abdusattor

texts.en: Y. Abdusattor is 39 years old and lives with his wife and four children. Abdusattor is an animal farmer. He owns cows and sells their milk with the help of his wife and elder son. In order to further develop his business, Abdusattor wants to take out a loan to buy one or two more cows and feed for them. After fattening them up, he will be able to sell them at a more favorable price. Then he will be able to use the profit from his business for the well-being of his family. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase one or two more cows and feed for them

loans.name: Souheir

texts.en: Souheir is a 22-year-old single woman living with her parents. In 2004, she decided to open a tailor shop and begin her new career. Now with six years of experience, Souheir is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase a machine and goods to develop her work.

loans.use: To purchase a machine and goods

loans.name: Nurbibi

texts.ru: Хамдамова Нурбиби проживает в Варзобском районе. Возраст 62 года. Вдова, имеет 3 детей. Сын находится на заработках в России. Сама клиентка занимается пашивом национальных платьев. Сырье закупает в городе Душанбе. Кредит просит для закупа сырья, чтобы предоставлять качественные услуги.
texts.en:
Nurbibi H. lives in the Varzob district. She is 62 years, a widow and has 3 children. Her son works in Russia. The client is involved in making traditional dresses. She buys her materials in the city of Dushanbe. She is requesting a loan for the purchase of materials in order to offer quality service.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of materials

loans.name: Hortencia Francisca

texts.es: Doña Hortensia Francisca de 62 años de edad, reside en el barrio Camilo Chamorro en la Capital de Managua, su esposo jubilado y con cinco hijos todos trabajan y casados, su negocio es la venta de mercadería variadas, como: cereales, frutas, ropa entre otros, lleva treinta años  en las ventas y da las gracias Afodenic por ayudar a proyectarse en sus objetivos ya que gracias a los prestamos ha logrado la inversión de su negocio es su décimo ciclo en, el cual va a comprar maíz, cacao, para hacer el pinolillo, comprar verduras y ropa para ofertar a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Doña Hortensia Francisca is 62 years old and lives in the Camilo Chamorro neighborhood in the capital city of Managua. Her husband is retired and they have five children, all of whom are married. Doña Hortensia sells all types of merchandise: grain, fruit, clothing, etc. She has been in business for 30 years and thanks AFODENIC for helping her meet her objectives.

Doña Hortensia is on her tenth loan cycle. She will use the funds to buy corn, cacao beans (for making pinolillo ), vegetables, and clothing to offer to her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase corn, cacao, vegetables, and clothing

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.es:
La señora MARIA ELENA  H. O. , tiene 53 años, vive en el distrito de Trujillo-Centro, provincia de Trujillo, departamento La Libertad – Perú.
Pertenece al Banco Comunal MANANTIAL DE VIDA
La empresaria presenta estudios hasta 5to de secundaria, tiene 4 hijos, todos mayores y ninguno depende económicamente de ella.
MARIA ELENA se dedica a la venta de menús (alimentos) que prepara en su domicilio y los lleva a repartir a los trabajadores de diferentes centros comerciales de la ciudad de Trujillo.
Su primer crédito de 300 nuevos soles lo invirtiró en la compra de productos alimenticios como: arroz, azúcar, menestras, aceites, papas al por mayor para preparar sus alimentos.
Este crédito de 1,000 nuevos soles lo invertirá en la compra de mas productos alimenticios y también en la compra de utensilios de cocina, vajillas y tapers para repartir sus menús.
MARIA ELENA sueña con tener un restaurante en su casa en dónde vender su menús , cervezas y gaseosas.

loans.use: compra de productos alimenticios y también en la compra de utensilios de cocina y vajillas

loans.name: Bebelyn

texts.en:
Bebelyn L., 30 years old, has a very supportive and responsible husband, 32-year-old Jodie L.. They have four children: nine-year-old Jodielyn, seven-year-old Shanely Ann Jane, Anthony Mark Louise and Ashley Rhell Jade.

One part of the family’s income comes from Jodie’s farming. They run a variety store selling daily necessities as well. Sometimes, however, Jodie works as a fisherman, but this pursuit is not very profitable. Not owning any fishing gear, he must borrow the equipment, which comes at a price: even though he may work hard out on the ocean, the one who owns the borrowed fishing gear demands a larger percentage than Jodie receives of the day’s take.

So Bebelyn is requesting a second loan from Kiva’s field partner, Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI). With this loan she will buy fishing gear, including a Robin boat motor, nylon rope and other things needed to start their own fishing business. Bebelyn will also help her husband sell their fish. This way Jodie and she will receive 100% in profits from the day’s catch.

Bebelyn would also like to use the loan to increase the items available at her variety store such as canned goods, cooking oil, refined sugar, detergent and other groceries. The variety store was Bebelyn’s idea so they could increase their income to meet everyday expenses and the cost of educating her four children.

loans.use: To be used for a new fishing business & to supplement her store's stock

loans.name: Jacinta Del Socorro

texts.es: Jacinta del Socorro T. es cliente de Fundación León 2000, ella es una buena cliente, además le gusta el servicio que se le ofrece.  La actividad económica a la que se dedica es la compra y venta de mercadería en general. Hace más de 12 años que se dedica a este negocio, es una mujer que ha aprendido muchas lecciones difíciles en la vida, pero siempre ha salido adelante, por lo que como todo comienzo fue difícil porque no tenía el capital de trabajo suficiente, pero con la ayuda de una amiga que le brindo el apoyo necesario logro comprar lo suficiente. Ahora solicita este financiamiento para capital de trabajo para la compra de ropa para damas, ropa para caballero, ropa para niños, calzado, cosméticos y perfumes. El mayor deseo que tiene es seguir adelante con sus metas propuestas.

loans.use: capital de trabajo

loans.name: Las Paraguayitas Group

texts.es:
This committee formed in the Emapalado Ari Neighborhood of the city of Caaguazú. Marta V. participated in a group of women that commissioned local women for promotion, and Fundación Paraguaya awarded small loans for women. They had much enthusiasm about it and decided to participate in the program, and they found 18 women to join. They invested in work that would increase their financial income. They have their own activities to sell such as clothes, shoes, fruits and vegetables, and more. Some took out loans of 800,000, others 500,000, and others 300,000 Gs. They are using their loans to buy sugar, meat, wheat, eggs, clothes, cheese, hens, and more from their loans awarded from Fundación Paraguaya. 
Marta V. V. wants to use her loan to sell fruits and vegetables. 
Benigna G. wants to use her loan for a chipera. 
María A. C. wants to use her loan to sell fruits and vegetables. 
Digna A. F. wants to use her loan to sell clothes. 
Ceferina C. D. P. wants to use her loan to sell clothes. 
Alodia V. C. wants to use her loan to sell fruits and vegetables. 
Alicia S. B. wants to use her loan to sell clothes. 
Hortencia G. wants to use her loan for a small grocery store. 
María A. C. wants to uer her loan to sell fruits and vegetables. 
Ramona A. wants to use her loan to sell clothes. 
Norma B. A. wants to use her loan to sell fruits and vegetables. 
Nidia A. C. wants to use her loan to sell clothes. 
Nidia B. G. C. wants to use her loan to sell candy. 
B. J. A. wants to use her loan to sell clothes. 
Ana K. C. wants to use her loan to sell undergarments. 
Ramona InsaurralD. wants to use her loan to be a hairdresser. 
Miguelina C. wants to use her loan for a small grocery store. 
Rosa G. InsaurralD. wants to use her loan for a small grocery store.

loans.use: Food, Clothes, etc.

loans.name: Ma. Linda

texts.en:
Ma. Linda O. is from Bucros, La Carlota City. She is 54 years old and married with four children, ages 10, 17, 22 and 24. She started her sorbets and homemade ice cream business 20 years ago, selling by the cone to the local community.  She also puts ice cream in tubes and barrels and sells using a mobile ice cream cart.  From one cart they are earning PHP4,000 a month but it isn't enough to sustain the needs of her family.  She wants to buy another ice cream cart.
--------------------------------
About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is a 36-year-old married woman with five children, aged between 3 and 10 years old. All her children go to school. She owns a five-room house where she lives with seven people. In addition, she takes care of other family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day.

She doesn’t incur transport costs to buy charcoal because she buys from delivery vans that pick up the charcoal from the villages and then deliver it directly to her home. She works in a semi-urban area, which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She owns a charcoal store in Kisaasi in Nsimbi Ziwoome zone. She sells both retail and wholesale. Sarah works seven days a week and receives an average of 25 customers a day. Besides her charcoal business, she also sells Airtime. Her major business challenges include thieves, ever increasing charcoal prices, the rainy season which hinders her customers from reaching her, and even the cost of transporting the charcoal.

Her monthly expenses include feeding the family and supplying medication. She has been in this business for over fifteen years and has been associated with MCDT for twelve years. Sarah is requesting her thirtieth loan, working with the same group mates. Sarah joined MCDT because it was near her home and also because she likes working in groups. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. She is aspires to grow her business so she can sell wholesale only.

loans.use: Buy sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase dairy and raw materials

loans.name: Jihad

texts.en:
Jihad is a 33 year old man who lives in Aley, Mount Lebanon with his parents. Jihad has owned a barber shop for ten years. Jihad has requested a loan from A. Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his work. This is the first time that Jihad has requested a loan. 
Jihad is speciA. in his work because he knows how to treat his clients. His clients are his friends and neighbors.  He decided on doing his business because he wanted to have independent work, as well as business  experience. In the future, Jihad plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase tools for his work.

loans.name: Guillermina's Group

texts.en:
1 Guillermina Domínguez, Cassava sales. 2 Florencia Espínola, Clothing sales 3 Amanda González, Clothing sales 4 Blásida S., Clothing sales 5 Fermina T., Fruit sales 6 Rosa V., Clothing sales 7 Inocencia S., Selling fruits and vegetables 8 Dora Arévalos, Jewelry sales 9 Rosa López, Grocery store 10 Alba López, Cantina 11 Ramona Díaz, Clothing sales 12 Alicia Álvarez, Cosmetic sales 13 Cristian V., Clothing and jewelry sales 14 Cyntia S., Clothing sales 15 Nilda Domínguez, Manicurist 16 Nardy Fernández, Manicurist 17 Norma B., Clothing sales 18 Epifania F., Beverage sales

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase basic necessity merchandise: clothing, beverages, fruit, vegetables, cassava; as well as other products: jewelry, cosmetics, etc.

loans.name: Toribio

texts.es:
Toribio pertenece al banco comunal “VIRGEN ASUNTA DE RACCHI” de la Asociación Arariwa.  El vive en el poblado de Racchí de la provincia de Urubamba del departamento del Cusco. Racchí esta a 45 minutos de la ciudad del Cusco.
 
Toribio tiene 36 años y trabaja como albañil. Actualmente esta trabajando en la construcción del Centro Educativo de Racchí. 
El socio requiere el préstamo para el gasto familiar y para su pequeño negocio de venta de verduras de su esposa. 

El socio se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Toribio, 36, is a member of Asociación Arariwa's “VIRGEN ASUNTA DE RACCHI” communal bank. He lives in Racchí, Urubamba province, Cusco department; Racchí is 45 minutes away from Cusco. He works as a bricklayer, currently working on the Racchí Educational Center construction project. He needs funding to meet household expenses and for his wife's small, vegetable sales business. He is grateful for the opportunity offered and pledges to repay in a timely fashion.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To meet household expenses and for his wife's small, vegetable sales business.

loans.name: Bibiraikhon

texts.en: F. Bibiraikhon is a fighting woman who has not allowed the passage of years to diminish the value of her work and, as such, has always set a solid example for many youths of today. Bibiraikhon was born in a clearly agricultural family that taught the hard work of tilling the land and also the joint effort of arduous work. She has been dedicated for twelve years to agriculture, sowing corn, potatoes and onions in an independent way. Bibiraikhon’s great wish is to provide for the studies of her three children and for this reason she works hard. At harvest time she sells directly in the wholesale market of her locality in order to obtain her profits. Bibiraikhon requests a loan to acquire a greater quantity of fertilizer with the objective of improving the quality of her produce. Support Bibiraikhon and her desire to work hard and improve her standard of living. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To sell food products

loans.name: Sandra Veronica

texts.es:
Sandra L. es socia del banco comunal Haciendo un mejor futuro está integrado por mujeres luchadoras, con una simpatía y carisma que nos hacen sentir como en familia durante las reuniones del banco, todas las socias viven  en la ciudad de Cuenca capital de la provincia del Azuay situada en la parte meridional de la Cordillera andina ecuatoriana; es la tercera ciudad de mayor importancia en el Ecuador y se caracteriza por mantener la tranquilidad y hermosura de una ciudad antigua. Su centro histórico fue declarado Patrimonio de la Humanidad por la Unesco en el año 1999.

 Nuestra socia vive en la comunidad Santa Anita en la parroquia Turi  con su hijo de 4 años y  su esposo que trabaja en la rama de la construcción y gracias a todo el esfuerzo en su unión conyugal se siente argullosa de tener su casa propia.

Ella vende productos nutricionales Herbalife, su horario de trabajo es de 9 a.m. hasta las 7 p.m., y se encuentra realizando esta actividad hace 2 años y le va bien ya que cuenta con su propia clientela, visita a sus clientes recorriendo toda su comunidad para ganar un poco mas de mercado es una tare muy dura y sacrificada ya que todo el día pasa fuera de casa y casi no comparte con su pequeño hijo.

Es socia activa del banco comunal hace  un año y con la ayuda en la fundación  ha ido incrementado su negocio, con el nuevo préstamo va a comprar vitaminas, y suplementos proteicos Herbalife para seguir creciendo con su negocio, su meta es terminar su casa ya que aún le falta algunos terminados.
texts.en:
Sandra L. is a member of the Haciendo un Mejor Futuro (Building a Better Future) communal bank, which is made up of tenacious women who, because of their good humor and charisma, make us all feel like one big family during bank meetings. All of the members live in the city of Cuenca, capital of Azuay province. It is located in the southern part of the Ecuadorean Andes. It is Ecuador’s third most important city and it is characterized by maintaining the tranquility and beauty of an old city. Its historic city center was declared a Patrimony of Humanity by Unesco in 1999. Sandra lives in Santa Anita, Turi parish with her 4-year-old son and her husband, who works in construction. Thanks to the joint effort of herself and her husband she is proud to have her own home. She sells Herbalife products. Her working schedule is from 9am to 7pm. She has been in this line of work for 2 years and she does well because she has steady customers. She visits them throughout the community to gain a bigger market share; this is hard and demanding work in that she spends all day away from home and hardly spends any time with her little boy. She has been an active member of the communal bank for a year. With help from the Foundation she has been expanding her business. She will use the new loan to buy vitamins and Herbalife protein supplements so that her business will continue to grow. Her goal is to finish her house since it still lacks some finishing touches.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy vitamins and protein supplements.

loans.name: Gloren

texts.en:
From Gloren T.’s various income generating activities, financed by the loan she received from ASHI, she has been able to have her own income. This has been a great benefit to her family’s basic needs, especially towards the educational needs of her children. Though it was hard for her to sustain three kinds of businesses (hog fattening, fish and rice selling), she has greatly enjoyed discovering her own capacity for managing her small finances.

With the support of her loving husband, Gloren now is requesting, from Kiva, another loan to be able to support the financial needs of her growing businesses. She hopes that once she has made it grow, she will also be able to increases her profits. This is her means to overcome poverty.

loans.use: To purchase piglets for fattening, rice and fish for selling.

loans.name: Berta Esperanza

texts.es: Doña Berta Esperanza, es una mujer muy dedicada al trabajo por lo que ella se dedica a la venta de mercadería en general, por lo que sus inicio se dan desde hace 8 años, por lo que no tenía un trabajo estable y fue por interés propio que ella decide iniciar con este negocio, a pesar que no tenía mucho capital de trabajo por lo que su gran ayuda fue los financiamientos que le brindaron lo necesario para salir adelante. Ella solicita este financiamiento porque se acerca la temporada de verano y quiere comprar nuevos productos. Su deseo es mantener activo este negocio.
texts.en:
Doña Berta Esperanza is woman who is very dedicated to her work. She sells general merchandise. Berta started her business eight years ago out of self-interest because she did not have a stable job. Despite not having much operating capital, the help she received from the loans has given her everything necessary to move forward.

The loan she is requesting will be used to buy new products for the upcoming summer season. Her wish is to keep this business active.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital to buy new products

loans.name: Tobias

texts.en:
Tobias O. A. is a farmer in Lwanyange village, Nambale divison, Busia District, Kenya. Before he started farming he was a car mechanic but he says he was well paid by his standards. Tobias, like all farmers in Nambale, plants and harvests twice a year.

Tobias would like a loan of Kshs. 20,000 to be used in expanding his farming area, to buy seeds and hire some labor for land preparation. His main plan is to guarantee education for his children to the highest level, as long as he is alive, he says. Tobias is 39 years old, married and blessed with 5 children.

loans.use: expand farming area

loans.name: Ekyerisho Traders, Mubende Group

texts.en:
With two children of his own and two dependents to take care of, 40-year-old, hard working, M. Emmanuel knows he has his responsibilites cut out for him. This reality has looked him in the face for the past seven years as he goes about his trivial round business of selling alcohol in Ekyerisho, Mubende District.

With his minimal 280,000 shillings a month of earnings, Emmanuel has faced long odds in providing all his family’s needs, principally his children’s education. He wants to improve on the status quo of his family with the acquisition of this loan as he wants to give his business an improved lease of life in terms of expansion through restocking.

loans.use: To restock and expand his business

loans.name: Susanita

texts.en:
Susanita M. is from the village of Pinamulaan, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 50 years old, married and has eight adult children. To make a living, Susanita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Susanita has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Susanita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Susanita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the third loan she has taken out from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Massanvi

texts.fr: Cette dame exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de  détail de parasol, les revendeuses au grand marché constituent une grande partie de sa clientèle car elle utilise les parasols pour se protéger des rayons du soleil en période de chaleur. Elle veut se réapprovisionner pour mieux vendre raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de 20 parasols. Elle est mariée et mère de trois enfants.
texts.en:
This is a lady who has a revenue-generating retail business involving parasols. The retailers at the big market constitute the bulk of her customer base because parasols are used for protection against the sun's rays during hot spells. She wants to stock up again to sell more. This is why she is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy 20 parasols. She is married and the mother of three children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying parasols

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane W. is currently in the business of selling fresh fish and tomatoes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock onions and cooking oil to sell.  Jane is 38 years old and is widowed.   She has 2 children who both go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to rent a house for her family.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock onions and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Juamonie

texts.en:
Juamonie S. is from the village of Villa Verde, Balulang, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 28 years old. Juamonie is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Juamonie owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from dealing and selling ready-to-wear clothing and shoe products in the local community. Juamonie has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4,700 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Juamonie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juamonie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Juamonie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

location.town: Villa Verde, Balulang, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Ori

loans.name: Martha Susana

texts.es:
Martha de 19 años, vive en Primavera de Duran (zona periurbana, con una ecología en disolución a las afuera de Guayaquil), hace unos meses atrás sus padres le dieron una tienda pequeña para Martha. 

Por la falta de oportunidades y al ver sus padres el empeño que ella tenia por independizarse decidieron comprar algunos víveres y ubicarle una tienda para Martha, poco a poco ella ha administrado la tienda, cuando sale en las noches a la universidad su mama le ayuda atender la tienda, vende arroz, bebidas, lácteos etc. 

Ella quiere continuar con su tienda e invertir en dinero comprando arroz y bebidas con el préstamo. En el futuro quiere surtir su tienda y terminar sus estudios con éxito.
texts.en:
Martha is 19 years old and lives in Primavera de Duran (an area outside the city of Guayaquil with a deteriorating ecosystem). A few months ago, her parents gave her a small store. Because of the lack of other opportunities, when her parents saw her determination to work independently, they decided to buy some groceries and create a store for Martha. Little by little, she has improved the store, and when she goes out at night to her university classes, her mother helps her by working in the store, selling rice, beverages, dairy products, etc. Martha would like to continue with her store and invest the funds from the loan to buy rice and beverages. In the future, she would like to expand the range of goods she sells and successfully complete her studies.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying rice and beverages for her store

loans.name: Samwel

texts.en:
Samwel has been practicing mixed farming for the last eight years in the town of Kitale in Western Kenya. His farm produces maize, beans, vegetables and milk, which he sells locally. He also runs a cereals business.

Samwel is 28 years old. He is married and has been blessed with three children who are between the ages of 20 months and 6 years. Two of his children attend school.

Samwel has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 36,400 Kenyan Shillings to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that with the income from this loan, his children will be able to access a good education and have good health. His primary challenge has been the changing weather patterns, which affect his production, and also theft in the area.

In the future, he hopes that he will be able to expand his 2-acre farm to 6 acres and keep four dairy animals with a poultry farm. He appreciates the loan from Juhudi and hopes it will be of great help.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Ave

texts.en:
Ave R. is 57 years old and is married to a carpenter. They have five children who are no longer living with them because they already have their own jobs and families to support. The remaining companion of the couple in their house is their 14-year-old granddaughter whom they fully support. They wanted to help their granddaughter pursue a career; that is why they have kept on working and earning. Also, the couple is getting older and they want to enjoy a better life and save in preparation for their retirement. 

For almost five years, the couple has been engaged in managing a variety store. Aside from the income of her husband, the profit from their store helped the family by providing for a good education among their children. This has continued to be their second source of income. 

Ave wanted to apply for another loan to buy a boat for her husband to use in fishing, a bicycle for delivery, a parcel of land for farming and additional grocery products to display in the store. She will also buy two sacks of sugar and ten sacks of charcoal. They also want to help their community by providing employment to people, and they will continue to support their family. 

They are hoping ASHI and KIVA will always be there to support their dreams in life. Ave R. is a very good member of Ahon sa HIrap, Inc.(ASHI)-Rizal Central Branch, a partner Micro-finance Institution of KIVA in the Philippines. Because of her very good performance, the branch chose her to be a recipient of a KIVA loan.

loans.use: to buy a boat, a bicycle and additional grocery products for her store

loans.name: Ganzorig

texts.en: Ganzorig D. is 47 years old and lives with his wife and three children in the Hentiy province in central Mongolia. His oldest two children currently attend university, and his youngest daughter studies at a local secondary school. His wife works as a construction decorator and earns a salary of 300,000-500,000 MNT during the summer months. He operates a small wood production business in his town. Ganzorig started his wood products business in 2002. By managing and conducting his business successfully he has been able to achieve stable operations, and his monthly revenue reaches up to 800,000 MNT. His earnings have enabled him to support his entire family as well as to operate his business sustainably. He is a helpful, honest and hardworking person. He dreams of opening his own wood production workplace after providing for his son's education. He is requesting a 740,000 MNT loan to buy more wooden timber for his business.

loans.use: To buy more wooden timber

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en: Rosita M. is a 50-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating three business ventures: fishing, fattening pigs and selling food. She lives in Prk. Tuboran, Brgy. Caghagan, Sipalay, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1999 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fishing, pig fattening and food vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). Rosita is now borrowing 20,000 PHP so that she can purchase fishing gear and equipment. This will be her 18th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 22,500 PHP (which she paid off well within its term) was just another step on her journey toward economic freedom. Rosita hopes to improve her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: For the purchase of fishing gear and equipment

loans.name: Matilde

texts.es:
Matilde es una madre de familia de 35 años de edad que reside junto a su esposo y a sus hijos en el sector Hualtaco del distrito de Tambogrande. Una zona agrícola que pertenece a la provincia de Piura y que se encuentra situada en la región del mismo nombre, a mas de tres horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo, capital de la región Lambayeque.

Se dedica a trabajar en labores asociadas a la agricultura. Al igual que la mayor parte de los pobladores de la zona se dedica a sembrar mango y limón en una pequeña extesión de terreno. Su esposo trabaja como albañil y juntos tratan de salir adelante y encargarse de los gastos de la familia.

Matilde desea brindar mantenimiento a su cultivo aplicándole algunos fertilizantes y pesticidas, por ello  ha creído conveniente solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1500 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en la compra de los productos que necesita.

Ella es una mujer tranquila y bastante entregada a su familia. Su mayor anhelo es seguir creciendo como empresaria para mejorar gradualmente su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Matilde, 35, is a mother living with her husband and children in Hualtaco, Tambogrande district, an agricultural area that is part of Piura province, Piura region, located over three hours from the city of Chiclayo, Lambayeque region capital.

She works in farming.  Like most area residents she plants mangoes and lemons in a small field.  Her husband works as a bricklayer and together they strive to get ahead and take care of family expenses.

Matilde wants to care for her crops applying fertilizers and pesticides.  She has applied for a 1500 new sol loan from Edpyme Alternativa to buy the necessary supplies to do so.

She is a mature woman who is quite dedicated to her family.  Her greatest wish is to continue growing as a businesswoman to gradually improve her quality of life.

loans.use: For mango and lemon crop maintenance costs.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys K. is thirty six years old. She is married with three school-aged children who all attend school. She has been farming for ten years in Kisii town, western Kenya. Her mixed farm produces maize, beans, bananas and milk which are all sold locally. She mainly depends on the income from her farm to cater to the needs of her family. Her primary challenge has been lack of financing to purchase farm inputs like fertilizer and animal feed.

She has requested this loan of 45,000KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow. The increased income from the sale of milk will help her improve her family's livelihood. In the future, she would like to expand her dairy farming and acquire at least five high quality dairy cows.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Janet Adjoa Mamfoah

texts.en: Janet Adjoa Mamfoah A. is a hairdresser at Abura. She is a single parent taking care of one child. Demand is increasing, and she is looking to expand her business. The loan will be used to make available hair products that are frequently requested by her customers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a shop and to purchase an additional dryer.

loans.use: buy hair products that are frequently requested by her customers

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta M. is 46 years old and runs a small clothing business and a farm. She lives in San Francisco, Agusan del Sur. She wants to improve her house and to expand her business. By planting rice and selling used clothes, she adds to her income, which is helpful in meeting all her family's needs. 

She has four children and she is supporting their education. She wants all of her children to succeed in their studies so that when they are older, they can find better employment and support the needs of their future families.

She chose CEVI because it has an insurance coverage package for all of its clients. She applied for a loan of 4,000 PHP which she will use to buy farm supplies and more used clothes to sell.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies and clothes to sell

loans.name: Mehrullo

texts.en:
Mehrullo, a farmer, lives with his family, comprised of his wife, two children and parents. His father helps him in the care of their land. In the past they have had problems in harvesting, forcing them to sell their crop in advance, thereby resulting in reduced earnings. Mehrullo has subsequently gained much business experience and now his crop is one of the most demanded at the market. Because his field is infertile, he has decided to request a loan to buy seed, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants to support the field and make his crop more productive.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes its role as a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seed, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants

loans.name: Ara

texts.en: Ara P. had been working abroad for several years. After saving some money, he returned to his homeland and invested in a trade business. He proved to be a successful businessman and a very client-oriented entrepreneur. Ara regularly updates his clothing stock, and has applied for this loan for that purpose.

loans.use: To purchase new clothing inventory.

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita B. is from the village of Nagrumbuan, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 57 years old. Nenita is married and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Nenita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Nenita has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 2500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Nenita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nenita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Nenita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Nenita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Lolo Group

texts.fr:
Lolo est un regroupement de 4 femmes ayant en moyenne 32  ans, 3 enfants et vivant  dans des familles nucléaires à Filabougou, un des quartiers de la ville Ouelessebougou de Koulikoro (2ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de pagnes avec BAOU G., d’habits pour enfants et des produits alimentaires.
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt,  12 pièces de pagnes wax. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché  de Bamako (capitale du Mali) auprès des grossistes. Ellle effectue sa vente au  marché de Ouelessebougou et à domicile à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes, en détail, au comptant et à crédit.
